title: Thursday, 1st September, 2016

11:02 am
PM

UK manufacturing fit as a fiddle

PM

Weak sterling helps manufacturers over the Brexit shock – The UK manufacturing PMI more than reversed the post-referendum drop to 48.2 in July and rose to 53.3 in August. The rebound exceeds our (49.3) and consensus (49.0) expectations. The index now points to growing activity in the sector, which accounts for 10% of total gross real value added.
Solid orders and activity, but caution in large companies’ employment plans – Markit reports that the joint-greatest monthly increase in the manufacturing PMI’s 25-year history was driven by solid inflows in domestic and export orders, aided by the weaker sterling exchange rate. In a sign that Brexit could be affecting longer-term investment plans, however, large-scale producers cut employment according to Markit.
Enough monetary stimulus? – The Bank of England expected “little growth in the second half of 2016” in its August Inflation Report (IR) but noted that the July crop of the PMIs, “which typically provides one of the better signals about activity, would by itself suggest a contraction in output in Q3”. If the sharp rebound in the manufacturing PMI is mirrored in the services PMI (published 5 September), which covers more than half of the UK economy, chances are that the MPC would not cut Bank Rate in November. The MPC had stated in August that “if the incoming data prove broadly consistent with the August IR forecast, a majority of members expect to support a further cut in Bank Rate”

PM

That's a citi snap

11:03 am
PM

Footsie celebrating with a fall of 6 points, currently

PM

The UK’s manufacturing purchasing managers’ index has bounced strongly in August, jumping five points from 48.3 to 53.3. This leaves the index at its highest level since last October and suggests that the UK economy is weathering the Brexit storm remarkably well.

Certainly the plunge in sterling is boosting the UK’s competitiveness, which is helping to support export orders, while the aggressive stimulus from the Bank of England and the smooth transition of political leadership has also helped calm immediate fears for the economy. This has allowed firms to restart work that had been postponed in the immediate aftermath of the Brexit vote. With retail sales looking solid, it suggests that the UK will post a respectable 3Q GDP reading, albeit down on the 0.6%QoQ rate recorded in 2Q16.

Nonetheless, the risks of recession have not disappeared and with surveys still suggesting a significant pullback on hiring and investment intentions we remain concerned about the prospect of a weaker performance around the turn of the year. Inflation will continue to rise due to higher import prices while wage growth is unlikely to strengthen meaning a squeeze on real household incomes. As such we still think policymakers will have more work to do. We still think the BoE will cut rates to 0.1% and we anticipate a fiscal response too given the Chancellor’s suggestion that he will look to “reset” fiscal policy.

PM

GBP's performance against the USD
• At the time of the Nixon Shock in August 1971 the price of GBP was USD 2.4195. Since then it has fallen 45.6% (as of yesterday morning).
• GBP has only seen 53 weekly closes below current levels against the USD since the Nixon shock.
• GBP spent from early July and late August 1984 trading between USD 1.30 and USD 1.34. When it finally resumed its downtrend at the very end of August it took six months for it to reach its recorded all-time closing low of USD 1.0520 (there remains some good natured debate amongst long standing members of the FX markets of what the absolute low actually was).
• There have been 7 distinct occasions since the Nixon shock when GBP has fallen by 15% or more against the USD over a 26 week period (based upon Reuters data). On 3 occasions (1981, 1992/3, 2008) when GBP fell more than 20% and one occasion (2008) when it fell more than 30%. GBP is currently down 10.65% against the USD from where it stood 26 weeks ago.
• The average 26 week decline during a downtrend is 6.3%.
• Prior to now there have been 9 distinct occasions since the Nixon shock when GBP has fallen by 15% or more against the USD over a 1-year period (based upon Reuters data). On 6 occasions (1976, 1981, 1985, 1992/3, 2008) when GBP fell more than 20% and one occasion (2008) when it fell more than 30%. GBP is currently down 16.34% from where it stood 12 months ago against the USD.
• The average y/y decline during a downtrend is 8.5%.

BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

FY16 EPS is 2% ahead of expectations driven by a powerful UK profit
performance and lower tax. UK perm activity stepped down after the EU
referendum then stabilised while temp has been more resilient (hence
divisional net fee growth has drifted further from -7% in June). However, there
has been no evidence of contagion into Europe. FY17E is highly uncertain but
Hays has navigated choppy waters before. We downgrade FY17-18E EPS by
4%-6%.

BE

Adjusted EPS is 2% ahead of expectations. Prelim EBITA was £181.0m (slightly ahead
of our £180.0m estimate) and a lower tax rate (30.0% versus JEFe 31.0%) offset slightly
higher net interest. Net fees, headcount and net cash were pre-announced in the Q4 IMS.
Impressive UK profitability offsets CEROW shortfall. Hays UK has demonstrated
admirably proactive cost discipline over the past few years and needed to remain nimble
in FY16. Net fee growth reversed from +9% to -7% within 12 months yet EBITA increased by 14%. Elsewhere, Asia Pacific EBITA was almost exactly in line with our £50.1m estimate but CEROW slightly undershot (£78.7m vs JEFe £82.6m) due to sustained headcount investment.

11:20 am
BE

UK perm drifts then stabilises; no Brexit impact overseas. Since the EU referendum,
perm activity stepped down then stabilised while temp has been more resilient, which
suggests that YOY UK net fee growth has drifted further from June’s -7%. Construction &
Property, London and larger corporates have been most impacted. To date, Hays has seen
no evidence of contagion into Europe. We are mindful that July and August are seasonally
quiet months for the industry and September (which can be one of the largest revenue
contributors of the year) will provide more meaningful insight.

BE

Trimming FY17E-18E EPS by 4-6%. Since early July, the tailwind to FY17E EBITA from
FX has increased by a mere c£0.5m and management reiterate their opinion that the UK
will have 3x operational gearing during any downturn and CEROW requires 10%+ net fee
growth to offset the cost of headcount expansion. Our EBITA estimates remain broadly
unchanged but we downgrade EPS to accommodate tax and interest guidance. We continue
to forecast a 7p special dividend alongside the FY17E final.
Valuation/Risks
Our 120p PT assumes: a trough 1.5x EV/net fee multiple to FY17E UK net fees; a 3.0x midcycle
EV/net fee multiple to ROW; and a 2.0x multiple to Europe. Risks include the shape of the
economic recovery and reviving UK profitability

BE

I think they're shop.

11:21 am
BE

And, oh, how about Barclays.

BE

Full year results in line, outlook firm apart from in the UK, which remains uncertain, although overall growth tracking slightly below exit rate from Q4 trading statement. The results are in-line, which is to be expected as the Q4 trading statement gave us growth numbers and operating profit. Operating profit came in at £181m, versus guidance of c£180m, EPS 8.5p (Barclays 8.4p) and net cash of £36m (guidance of c£40m). The breakdown of operating profit by region saw the UK 3% ahead of our estimate for the second half, Asia Pac 11% ahead, and Continental Europe & Rest of World 6% below. The outlook gives detail for each region; UK saw pressure on permanent activity post Brexit but is sequentially stable now. The July exit rate of -7% is now tracking more like -11% to -13% (Barclays -25%). CE & Row is seeing no impact from Brexit with strong growth in Germany and France (Barclays +14%). Australia is growing well (Barclays +5%) but Asia tough due to weakness in banking (Barclays -1%). The group exit rate at the Q4 trading statement was +5% and it’s now tracking +2% to +3% (Barclays -2%). September is the key month of the quarter, however. Overall it’s striking a cautiously optimistic tone but uncertainty remains elevated. Hays shares are currently trading on c17x FY17E PE. This compares to average trough multiples 8x and mid-cycle averages of 15x.

BE

Outlook/current trading:

· Australia - Group is seeing good levels of growth in Australia with stable conditions in the mining-dominated state of Western Australia. We interpret this as high single digit growth for July/august. We forecast 5% growth for the quarter.

· Asia - Subdued performance in Hong Kong and Singapore due to their high exposure to banking (Barclays -1% in the first quarter).

· Europe – Growth remains strong overall despite tough comps. Germany and France continue to perform well, with conditions also remaining strong in most markets in Rest of Europe and Americas. There is currently no evidence of contagion for the European division following Brexit. We forecast growth of c14% in net fees in the region within the first quarter and c7% growth for the full year.

· UK – Group cites the market as ‘tough but broadly sequentially stable’. There was a step down in perm activity immediately following the EU referendum but the region has since then been broadly stable. The referendum impact is still said to be unclear but Hays notes caution, particularly in the Perm market. The exit rate at the end of Q4 was -7% and July/August is tracking at -11% to -13%. Management is saying it is simply too early for the group to determine whether trends will continue beyond the summer period. We forecast a 25% decline in net fees in the UK in the first quarter and -18% for full year 2017.

· Tax guidance for the year of 30-35%. Lower profits in the UK would mean higher taxes. We forecast 32%.

11:22 am
BE

Regional profit and margin performance: UK broadly in line, CEROW weaker and Asia Pac ahead

· UK & Ireland – EBIT of £52.1m was c2% ahead our estimate of £51.3m with margins of 19.2%, a c30bps ahead of our estimate, driven by a 2% increase in productivity, lower headcount and reduced incentives due to weaker fee growth.

· CEROW – Operating profit of £78.7m was 3% below our £81.2m estimate, with a conversion rate of 21.7%, 60bps below our expectations mainly due to investment in new consultant headcount, mainly in new consultant headcount in countries such as Germany, France and US. Net fees grew by 15% in the full year.

· Asia Pacific – EBITA of £50.2m was c6% ahead of our £47.5m estimate with a conversion rate of 28.5%, c130bps ahead of our estimate which was impacted by currency movements. Net fee growth in the region was up 4% with operating profit up 8%.

BE

PM

11:30 am

BE

BE

11:33 am
PM

hehehe

BE

Anyway, here's Citi to push Reckit and Unilever.

BE

European Food & HPC multinationals are the product of an ecosystem favoring international scale and monopoly rents. We think this model has changed for good. Such an ecosystem works when supported by proper barriers to entry, which we believe was not the case in the space. The rise of digital, input cost and FX volatility have altered the industry cost structure, opening the door to disruptive new entrants and crystallizing incumbents’ vulnerability.

11:34 am
BE

Why does the rise of digital affect the sale of beans? I'm unclear.

BE

As incumbents’ sales growth comes under pressure, we think it is time to focus on costs. However, replicating the Kraft Heinz experience or using M&A are obvious, but risky, answers.

BE

Our work on cost structure and market shares suggests that gross margin is the first line of defense against category disruption, and companies than can act on it are better placed to secure their monopoly rents and sustain high-single-digit EPS growth. As execution becomes almost secondary in such context, we assess companies’ ability to cope with this ecosystem against a backdrop of demanding valuation and margin expectations.

11:34 am
BE

We think Danone, Reckitt and Unilever offer a combination of gross margin potential, self-help and good category specifics. Our portfolio analysis suggests that Nestlé could deliver a new model of 7% pa EPS growth supported by active mix management.

BE

We fear margin expectations do not yet reflect how disruptive brand proliferation and consumer fragmentation are for L’Oréal and Beiersdorf cost of growth. We initiate on both names with a Sell. We fear Henkel margins have been optimized already and see limited leeway for more aggressive target, and initiate at Neutral.
Data Summary

BE

I'm going to keep going on this, because there's clearly a lot of thought behind it.

11:35 am
BE

Our overarching thesis is that such model is sustainable when secured by proper barriers to entry, but in the case of European Food &HPC, we believe that these barriers were vulnerable from the start. Technological disruption (digital) and cost/FX volatility have destabilized these models based on size and international rollout, by altering industry cost structure and opening the door to new entrants, brand proliferation and consumer fragmentation. We believe that cosmetics companies have been the most disrupted by this change, as monopolizing access to expensive traditional media with deep A&P had indirectly contributed to build an oligopolistic discipline. Food & Home Care never had the same “luxury”, given their cost structure, and have thus started their work on mix, gross margin and portfolio at an earlier stage.

BE

In such context, we are not surprised to see multinationals finding it increasingly difficult to generate consistent and stable volume growth (forced pricing in EM to manage FX headwinds did not help, and the jury is out on the long-term impact of these price moves for some markets). However, we would argue that maintaining a 50% PE sector premium to the market, albeit inflated for other exogenous reasons, may demand more clarity on the alternatives these companies could find to control their new ecosystem.

BE

In our view, if volumes are hard to reignite, and if pricing, after several quarters of counterproductive hikes in EM (while deflation in Europe is also making pricing management in mature markets difficult), is too dangerous to use, working on cost structure sounds like the obvious answer to drive earnings. However, while we are supportive of the “3G model”1 for the culture change it can bring, our analysis suggests that fully replicating the model to European multinationals may prove too disruptive in the medium term. That said, we feel some companies and categories could apply ZBB (“Zero Based Budgeting”, a management and cost savings approach we discuss later in the note) selectively, under some criteria.

BE

11:45 am
BE

Redde has reported strong revenue and earnings growth for FY16 driven by both
organic growth in new and existing relationships, and an 8 month contribution from
FMG, acquired in October 2015. 53% revenue growth is indicative of strong
momentum, which is reinforced by management comment on positive performance
in the first two months of FY17e. This could drive outperformance against our forecasts.
The board has declared a 5.15p final dividend (vs N+1Se 5.0p).

BE

Redde has reported a strong set of full year
results, in line with our forecasts. This
delivered on previous indications of strong
underlying operational growth and
complemented by the acquisition of FMG
(completed Oct’15). Revenues grew by
53% (28% excl. FMG) whilst overall adj. EBIT
was £34.5m (+55% yoy) including a £4.0m 8
month contribution from FMG. Adj. f.dil EPS
was 9.2p (+17%). The group ended the year
with a small £5.2m net debt balance (vs
N+1Se £1.7m net cash) with additional fleet
investment. The board has declared a
5.15p final dividend (vs N+1Se 5.0p) which
will go ex on 6/10 and be paid on 3/11.

BE

The group has undergone an impressive
transformation over the last 4 years. Future
growth will be driven by cross-fertilisation
between existing divisions and organic
growth, through additional case flows from
existing partners and securing new
relationships. These opportunities provide
the potential to outperform, although we
do not yet incorporate this upside into our
forecasts. In addition, balance sheet
resource and flexibility remains should an
attractive acquisition opportunity present
itself.

11:46 am
BE

We leave our prior FY17e/FY18e forecasts
materially unchanged but have made
some minor amendments incorporating the
FY16 outturn. Momentum is positive and the
trading performance in H2’16 stands to
drive good earnings growth in FY17e.
Management outline that trading
performance in the first two months of the
year is already ahead of initial expectations
and last year.

BE

Redde is delivering strong profitability and a
sustainable yield. Long term growth
initiatives could drive further
outperformance, which is not yet reflected
in our forecasts. We note the 5.2% forecast
dividend yield in FY17e, and would also
highlight that the declared 5.15p FY16 final
dividend alone offers a 2.6% return for a
month holding period to ex-dividend on 6th
October.

Rolls-Royce Holdings PLC (RR.:LSE): Last: 771.38, up 1.38 (+0.18%), High: 777.00, Low: 764.50, Volume: 1.50m
11:55 am
BE

BE

BE

11:56 am
BE

ANA’s issues with Trent 1000 engines powering its 50 B787 aircraft are
evidently headline grabbing and clearly not good news for RR, but we believe
RR may have identified the issue as long as nine months ago. The issue appears
to be what is dubbed “hot corrosion” – and that is certainly not an unusual
issue with gas turbines, in our view. We believe ANA’s handling of the matter is
insightful and probably also comforting for the layman.

BE

ANA and the B787. In January 2013, an ANA B787 was forced to make an emergency
landing due to a malfunction related to batteries. In October 2015, ANA announced that it
would post information of any B787 malfunctions on its website pages and would include
cancellations and destination changes for the B787 along with those of other aircraft types.
In June 2016, for example, ANA’s operational data shows 99.29% of flights were serviced
with 0.1% of flights cancelled for maintenance (so, 1 in a 1,000). The turn back rate once
airborne was 0.076% with aircraft issues (“ship trouble”) accounting for 0.013% and the
divert rate was 0.042% with ship trouble representing 0.004%.

PM

Hmm -- the Reuters take is rather more alarming

11:58 am
BE

Yes, it's the difference I guess between an ANA spok guiding the story and a Rolls one.

BE

International and Domestic. ANA states that in February and March 2016, two B787
flights – one from Kuala Lumpur to Narita, the other from Hanoi to Haneda - had to return
to their departure airports due to engine-related irregularities. The Trent 1000 issue hence
first arose on international flights and it appears RR and ANA had been working to resolve
the problem since March 2016, with ANA stating: “According to analysis by Rolls-Royce, the
issue was determined to be fatigue cracks in the blades of the engine’s intermediate pressure
turbine. Such cracks are the result of sulfidation corrosion caused by chemical components in the
atmosphere, and the propagation of these cracks correlates with the number of flight cycles that
an engine has been used for”. This is often referred to as “hot corrosion”. The issue initially
related to B787s used on international routes, not to aircraft used on domestic routes.

BE

The atmospheric knife. ANA states: “Aircraft operating on international routes fly through
airspace which have higher atmospheric concentrations of the chemical components in question
and their engines also produce higher temperature exhaust gases due to greater power output.
These factors were determined to be more likely to generate fatigue cracks. Therefore, we
implemented a program to determine the number of flight cycles at which intermediate pressure
turbine blade cracks could occur based on analysis of each engine’s flight environment and
flight cycle count, and engines have been systematically replaced before that number of flight
cycles is reached”. ANA did not anticipate B787 aircraft used on domestic routes to have the
same issue as the airspace has lower concentrations of the chemical components in question
and the engines also have a lower power output. ANA did not, therefore, plan on a systematic
replacement of the IPT turbine blades. Then, the same issue arose with a domestic flight on
20 August at which point ANA decided to replace the engines on aircraft used for domestic
operations earlier than what was designated by Rolls-Royce

BE

Hot corrosion. From what we have read, possible solutions to hot corrosion include new
coatings for the turbine blades, the use of different alloys and, possibly, slight adjustments
to the temperature at which the particular engine stage operates (although this can have
repercussions elsewhere). Large aero engines are the equivalents of thoroughbreds and take
time to settle down and be matured to a point where reliability is optimised, in our view.
Regardless, in 1H16, RR took a charge of £55m in respect of “technical costs” (and may have
signaled it in November 2015) that we believe means RR was aware of reliability issues with
the Trent 1000. We believe the main conclusion to be drawn from this is that transitioning
from mature, proven engines to new engines poses a headwind to profits, but that has been
well-flagged by RR and can surely be no surprise.

The end of an ecosystem based on size — European Food & HPC multinationals are the product of an ecosystem favoring international scale and monopoly rents. We think this model has changed for good. Time to focus on costs as top line loses consistency — As incumbents’ sales growth comes under pressure, we think it is time now focus on costs. Fixing gross margin, a new imperative — Cost structure and market shares suggest that gross margin is the first line of defense against category disruption. Buying names where portfolio management offers self-help — We think Danone, Reckitt and Unilever offer a combination of gross margin potential, self-help and good category specifics. Are HPC margin expectations consistent with industry disruption? — Margin expectations do not yet reflect how disruptive brand proliferation and consumer fragmentation are for L’Oreal and Beiersdorf cost of growth. We initiate on both names with a Sell.
